Dear Rebecca Ketchum:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
1

rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of resident.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 05/29/2024, Youth A pulled Youth B into his room, closed the
door, and ran his hands up and down her body. The touching
occurred over clothing with no penetration occurring. Youth B has
been assaulted in the past and this triggered her. The staff were
made aware and ensured the children remained separate.
Investigation A second intake regarding these allegations was received on
5/30/24 which stated “Last night, Youth B pulled Youth A into his
room and locked the door. He attempted to kiss, hump, and rape
her. Youth C heard Youth A screaming and pushed the door in
with his shoulder. Staff was made aware, separated the youth,
and have kept them a part”.
A third intake regarding these allegations was received on 7/5/24
which stated, “On an unknown date, Youth B raped Youth A. Staff
was told about the sexual assault, and they didn't do anything.
The details of the sexual assault are unknown.”
INTERVIEWS:
All interviews were conducted separately, face to face at the
facility on 5/30/24.
Staff 1 reported on 5/29/24, he was passing medications to youth
while the other staff were in the main area of the facility. He
reported Youth A came into the medication room and told him
Youth B pulled her into his room, wouldn’t let her out, and ran his
hands all over her body. Staff 1 reported he went into the bedroom
hallway and provided supervision to ensure Youth A and Youth B
were separated. Staff 1 reported he has told youth and staff
almost every day for the last two weeks youth cannot be in each
other’s rooms. Staff 1 reported the supervision policy is youth
need to always be in line of sight, but sometimes youth require 1:1
supervision and Youth A is one of those youth. Staff 1 reported no
staff were specifically assigned to any of the youth on 5/29/24, but
all staff should know youth are not allowed to run in the facility or
go into each other’s rooms. Staff 1 reported Youth B is very
handsy with female staff, but he always corrects Youth B when he
sees it. Staff 1 reported he has noticed Youth B trying to get closer
to Youth A, but it’s normally seen in the form of roughhousing
rather than any inappropriate touching. Staff 1 reported Youth B
hasn’t had a safety plan in place for boundaries or supervision
prior to this incident. Staff 1 reported as of today, the facility is
2

assigning each youth to a specific staff for supervision to ensure
nothing like this happens again.
Youth A reported she was playing tag in the bedroom hallway
with Youth B and Youth C. Youth A reported she went into Youth
B’s bedroom two times on 5/29/24 when they were playing. Youth
A reported the first time she went into Youth B’s room, Youth B
shut the door, but nothing happened. Youth A reported the second
time, Youth B pushed her into his bedroom, and shut the door.
Youth A reported Youth B had one of his hands holding the door
shut so she couldn’t get out of his room, and Youth B’s other hand
was rubbing all over her body on top of her clothes. Youth A
reported she told Youth B to stop, and then Youth C pushed the
door open, so Youth B stopped. Youth A reported she left Youth
B’s bedroom and immediately found Staff 1 and told him what
happened. Youth A reported there were no staff in the hallway
watching them until she told Staff 1 what happened. Youth A
reported there were staff in the living room, which is by the
bedroom hallway, but she couldn’t remember who.
Youth B reported he and Youth A went into Youth B’s bedroom
one time. Youth B reported Youth A was leaning with her back up
against his closed bedroom door, and he pretended to kiss Youth
A, but didn’t do it. Youth B reported he put his hand against the
door so Youth A couldn’t leave the room, but when Youth A told
him to stop, he stopped. Youth B reported he and Youth A were
playing a game called “booty bump” which is where you turn
around and bump your butts together. Youth B reported when he
and Youth A were playing in the hallway and went into his
bedroom, there were no staff around, and he didn’t know where
staff were.
Staff 2 reported on 5/29/24 he was sitting in the living room
watching TV with Youth D. Staff 2 reported he did not hear any
youth cry or scream for help. Staff 2 reported he only heard playful
screams from Youth A, Youth B and Youth C because they were
running around playing with each other. Staff 2 reported he
thought Staff 3 or Staff 4 were down the bedroom hallway
supervising the youth, so he wasn’t aware they were
unsupervised. Staff 2 reported staff are not assigned to supervise
certain youth during their shift. Staff 2 reported Youth A went to
get Staff 1 and Staff 1 went down the hallway with her. After Youth
A told Staff 1 and Staff 2 what happened, Youth A asked if she
could go to Youth B’s room and talk to him since he was in his
room. Staff 2 reported he told her she could not go in Youth B’s
room but could talk to him while she was in the hallway. Youth A
3

stood outside Youth B’s room and told Youth A what he did to her
reminded her of something that happened to her in her past, and
said she needed a couple days away from him. Staff 2 reported
Youth B apologized to Youth A, and they went their separate
ways. Staff 2 reported Youth B has a lot of boundary issues with
youth and staff. Staff 2 reported when youth or staff express their
desire to have certain boundaries in place, Youth B says people
are being mean. Staff 2 reported he thought Youth B had a safety
plan in place regarding keeping a safe distance from others prior
to this incident but couldn’t give any specifics about the safety
plan. Staff 2 was unable to provide any specifics regarding what
the facility’s supervision policy states but thought staff must be
within a safe distance to supervise youth.
Staff 3 reported Youth B wanted to build a fort in his room, but the
whole staff team is trying to stop forts from being built. Staff 3
reported Youth B invited Youth A and Youth C into his room to
help build a fort, and Staff 3 reported she was supervising them
from the hallway. Staff 3 reported Youth C wanted to go outside,
so she took Youth C outside. Staff 3 reported when she went
outside with Youth C, Youth A and Youth B were still in Youth B’s
room together. Staff 3 reported she told other staff (couldn’t
remember who) she was going outside with Youth C, and
assumed someone would supervise Youth A and Youth B. Staff 3
reported she didn’t directly tell any staff to supervise Youth A and
Youth B because it’s not her job to tell other staff what to do. Staff
3 reported after she brought Youth C back inside, Youth A, Youth
B and Youth C were running up and down the hallway with each
other. Staff 3 reported she thought she was in the hallway
supervising them, but when she was told the camera did not show
her in the hallway, she reported she didn’t know where she was.
Staff 3 reported Youth A pulled each staff aside to tell them what
happened between her and Youth B in Youth B’s bedroom shortly
before bedtime. Staff 3 reported she had only been working at the
facility for two weeks and could not reiterate the requirements of
the facility’s supervision policy. Staff 3 reported there’s been a
couple times staff have been assigned specific youth to supervise
during their shift, but most of the time they’re not.
Staff 4 reported she went outside with Staff 3, Youth A, Youth B,
and Youth C before 7:00PM. Staff 4 reported Staff 3 brought
Youth C in a little earlier, and she remained outside with Youth A
and Youth B. Staff 4 reported around 6:55PM, she brought Youth
A and Youth B inside, and told them to go to their rooms so she
could go to the kitchen and make them a snack. Staff 4 reported
she didn’t know what other staff were present, what they were
4

doing or where they were, but believed they were within sight of
Youth A and Youth B when she brought them inside. Staff 4
reported she did not directly communicate with any staff they
would need to supervise Youth A and Youth B because she was
going to make a snack, but thought the other staff were in the
same area and heard when she told the youth she was going to
the kitchen. Staff 4 reported normally staff are not assigned
specific youth to supervise during the shift, but it has happened a
couple times. Staff 4 reported moving forward, staff are going to
be assigned specific youth to supervise during the shift because of
this situation. Staff 4 reported she had only been working at the
facility for three weeks, so she was not sure about the
requirements of the supervision policy but feels youth should
always be in staff’s line of sight. Staff 4 reported Youth B is very
touchy with female staff (i.e. hugs, wanting to lay on staff, bit her
nipple recently), but she has never seen Youth B be this way with
Youth A before. Staff 4 reported she wasn’t sure if Youth B had a
safety plan in place prior to this incident.
Supervisor reported neither Youth A nor Youth B had a safety
plan in place for boundaries prior to the incident occurring on
5/29/24. However, Youth A is approved for and supposed to
receive 1:1 supervision.
VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage from 5/29/24 from 6:53-7:10PM was reviewed. Staff
4, Youth A and Youth B are seen entering the facility from playing
outside. Staff 3, Staff 4, Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C in the
bedroom hallway. Staff 4 exits the hallway, and then Staff 3 also
leaves the hallway. Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C are still in the
hallway together. Youth A enters Youth B’s bedroom and Youth B
is standing in the doorway. Then Youth A and Youth B enter the
bedroom and shut the door. Within seconds, the door is open, but
then is closed again. Youth C pushes the door open, and Youth A
exits the room. Youth B remains in his bedroom for a minute, then
exits. Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C are playing in the hallway.
Youth B then pushes Youth A against the wall in the hallway, tries
to hold her still, and attempts to kiss her. Youth A fights to get out
of his hold and runs down the hallway. No staff are present in the
hallway watching them. Staff 3 comes back into the hallway, but
then leaves again. Youth B and Youth A go down the bedroom
hallway and into Youth B’s bedroom. The bedroom door is shut,
but left cracked, and the two youth come out within seconds. Right
afterwards, Youth A and Youth B go back into Youth B’s bedroom
and shut the door all the way. They’re in Youth B’s room for
approximately 30 seconds before they come out of the bedroom
5

and go back down the hallway. Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C
continue walking and running up and down the bedroom hallway
multiple times. A few minutes later, Youth C pushes Youth A into
Youth B’s room and shuts the door, while Youth C is in the
hallway. Then Youth B pushes Youth C out of the way, and Youth
A exits Youth B’s room. The three youth continue to run up and
down the bedroom hallway multiple times. No staff are present in
the hallway. Youth A and Youth B begin roughhousing in the
hallway, including Youth B putting his arms around Youth A’s
waist. Youth A pushes Youth B away, and the three youth
continue to run up and down the hallway. At 7:08PM, Youth A
enters Youth B’s room, and Youth B follows her into his room and
shuts the door. Less than a minute later, Youth C uses his
shoulder and bangs up against the door. Youth A comes out of the
room and runs down the hallway. Youth B walks out of his room
and stays in the hallway. Less than a minute later, Youth A comes
back into the hallway with Staff 1 and they’re having a
conversation. At 7:10PM, Staff 1 sits in a chair in the hallway and
provides supervision.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• House Rules for the facility states:
o Youth are to keep their hands to themselves (i.e. no
touching, handholding, hugging).
o Youth should not ever stand in a peer’s doorway or
enter another peer’s room.
o Staff must always have sight of youth and
accompany youth everywhere (except bathrooms
and school).
• Staffing Requirements and Supervision Policy (rev.
11/1/23) states staff will provide supervision as specified in
the youth’s service plan.
• Youth A’s Updated Residential Service Plan dated 5/1/24
states while in general areas of the home, staff will provide
visual supervision to ensure safety. It states Youth A is on
1:1 supervision due to her behaviors.
• Letter from Executive Director dated 2/29/24 requesting 1:1
supervision approval for Youth A from 3/12/24-6/9/24.
• Email dated 6/6/24 from Executive Director stating Youth A
was supposed to be on 1:1 staffing on 5/29/24. In addition,
the facility does not have a specific policy outlining the 1:1
supervision requirement for staff.
6

• Youth B’s Initial Residential Service Plan dated 5/8/24
states while in general areas of the home, staff will provide
visual supervision to ensure Youth B’s safety. The
Genacross Service Plan rating tool notes Youth B has a
history of, or mild concern, for sexualized behavior. The
service plan does not identify any concerns related to being
handsy towards female staff or boundary issues as was
reported during interviews with staff.
• Staff 1 does not have any disciplinary actions in his
employee file. Staff 1 was trained on the supervision policy,
1:1 supervision, and house rules during orientation in
August 2023.
• Staff 2 does not have any disciplinary actions in his
employee file. Staff 2 was trained on the supervision policy,
1:1 supervision, and house rules during orientation in
January 2024.
• Staff 3 and Staff 4 do not have any disciplinary actions in
their employee files. Staff 3 and Staff 4 were trained on the
supervision policy, 1:1 supervision, and house rules during
orientation in May 2024.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance based on video footage
reviewed, interviews conducted, and documentation reviewed.
Although the facility had a sufficient number of staff present on
5/29/24, staff failed to comply with supervision standards set forth
by the facility’s policy, facility’s house rules, and did not abide by
Youth A’s 1:1 supervision requirement.
Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance was offered as follows:
• The agency to update their supervision policy to reflect
the following:
• What staff are required to do if a youth does not have a
specific safety or supervision plan. House rules reflect
staff must always have sight of youth and accompany
youth everywhere, but supervision policy does not.
• In the same sense, the supervision policy states staff
will provide supervision of youth based on what’s in the
youth’s service plan. However, the general language in
the case service plans for youth state “while in general
areas of the home, staff will provide visual supervision
of youth”, which is not consistent with the house rules.
7

• If there is going to be a requirement of specific youth
being assigned to specific staff during the shift, the
policy should reflect that as well.
• Requirements of staff for youth who have a 1:1
supervision plan should be clearly defined.
• Staff have clear and direct communication with each
other when they are no longer providing line of sight
supervision for youth.
• Ensure service plans document and safety plans are
developed to address boundary concerns with youth as
Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 4 reported Youth B has
boundary issues, especially with female staff, but those
concerns were not reflected in his service plan, and
there was no established safety plan.
• Establish process to ensure staff are made aware of
specific supervision requirements for youth.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR #2023C0000500 dated 7/15/23; CAP approved 9/11/23
SIR #2023C0000532 dated 7/5/23; CAP approved 8/15/23
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
